div.p: SPRIGS OF LAUREL: A COMIC OPERA. IN TWO ACTS.
SPRIGS OF LAUREL: A COMIC OPERA.
AS PERFORMED, WITH UNIVERSAL APPLAUSE, AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN.

Author of Tony Lumpkin in Town; The Son in Law; The Agreeable Surprize; The Poſitive Man; The Caſtle of Andaluſia; The Poor Soldier; The Beggar on Horſeback; Fontainbleau, or Our Way in France; Peeping Tom; The Young Quaker, a comedy in five acts; The Toy, or Hampton Court Frolicks, ditto; Wild Oats, or The Strolling Gentleman, ditto; Modern Antiques, or The Merry Mourners; The Farmer; The Priſoner at Large; The Birth Day, or Prince of Arragon; Siege of Curzola; Little Hunchback; The Highland Reel; Love in a Camp, or Patrick in Pruſſia, &c. &c.
LONDON: PRINTED BY H. S. WOODFALL, FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW. 1793.

div.head: DEDICATION.
To Her Moſt Excellent Majeſty the QUEEN.
div.p: AS a ſmall tribute of congratulation on the patriotic ardor diſplayed by her Majeſty's Illuſtrious Son, His Royal Highneſs the Duke of York, and the early proofs he has given that a future career of glory will render him a brilliant example of military ſkill, bravery, and humanity to the Britiſh Troops, and their Leader the Defender of his Country.
This Opera is with all poſſible humility laid at her feet, by her Majeſty's faithful ſervant and Dutiful Subject,

div.head: A CARD.
div.p: Mr. O'Keeffee owes his firſt Thought of writing this Piece, to a Circumſtance he had heard of a Centinel quitting his Poſt, to follow the Detachment from the Guards when it embarked at Greenwich: But whether a Fact, or Fiction, he is happy if it has afforded any Pleaſure from the Popularity of the Occaſion, the ſweet Melodies of Mr. Shield, and the zealous Exertion of the reſpective Performers.

div.head: SPRIGS OF LAUREL. A COMIC OPERA.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN.
sp.p: LEAVE my infant in a baſket at a gentleman's door, you villain? when I ordered that your wife ſhou'd bring it up with care and tenderneſs.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Why, ſir, when my wife ſaid it was my infant, and woudn't take charge on't, what was a poor honeſt peace-loving huſband to do?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well; come, your intelligence?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p:
The babe was taken in and chriſten'd Tommy Jones—the gentleman of the houſe intended to do well by't; but being given to play, died inſolvent; his family went to ruin, and poor Tommy to the pariſh—the lazy overſeers farm'd the workhouſe to the village butcher, who, to feed his calves, ſtarved the children;
here, like a young negro, he got hard work, many blows, and no learning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And from this miſery, a charitable tradeſman took him prentice.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; ſerved out his time with honor; but his ſpirit too noble for a mechanic, he liſted, and is this moment a gentleman common ſoldier in the foot-guards.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But how to find him out—?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: That we're to find out—In my ſearch I got acquainted with two honeſt ſoldier lads—Ned Lenox and Jack Sinclair, and they're to bring me among the reſt—the ſerjeant major Tactic, that has got the pretty daughter, may know.—I'll run a hum upon him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nipperkin, you were my ſervant twenty years back; but ſince that you've been ſuch a variety of raſcal, there's no truſting you now.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: I want no truſt—give me a ready guinea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To get drunk and neglect this buſineſs—no, diſcover my poor loſt ſon, and you ſhall have a hundred, to ſettle you in a farm, ſirrah.—John!(calls.) Enter a ſervant with cane, hat and ſword. I muſt get off to Greenwich, ready to receive the Duke.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: But, ſir, I intend this evening viſiting my old father at Chelſea—A little comfort for the honeſt ſoul.—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Chelſea! oh, your father a penſioner! well, there (gives money) but uſe every endeavour to find the boy, mind.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p:
You ſhall ſettle on me one hundred a
year, or find the boy yourſelf. Lucky, that ſtill keeping an eye to the lad's progreſs through life, I've this pull upon my old maſter—Till he bids more I'll not bring father and ſon together—now got looſe from my wife, I'll make a good uſe of my time—damme, ſince I'm come to London, I'll drink like a foul, and divert myſelf with the girls;—if not, I'd be a man in a thouſand!

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Shew me a Lawyer refuſing a good fee,
Or pious Dean not thinking of a Biſhop's fee,
A Doctor who won't ſqueeze ſick Ladies by the hand,
'Potticary whom his ſcrawl can well underſtand,
Dancing-maſter object to dancing off with Miſs,
A Methodiſt Preacher, not in a corner kiſs,
Young Enſign not proud of his flaſhy large cockade,
Or true Britiſh Tar, who of Frenchmen is afraid—
Parliament Elector, who never ſold his vote,
Parliament Orator, who will not turn his coat,
And that is a man in a thouſand.
Tol lol de rol.

lg.head: II
lg.l: Shew me a Right Honorable keeping to his word,
Or a poor Poet patroniz'd by a Lord,
An impudent Sharper cloathed all in rags,
Or modeſt Genius counting o'er his money-bags,
A Church-warden who ſcorns to feaſt upon the poor,
Fat Alderman who cannot calipaſh endure,
A Groom too honeſt to rob horſes of their corn,
Wife Cuckold who bluſhes to wear a gilded horn,
Sportſman mind galloping over corn or ſtubble,
Or Secretary of State take nothing for his trouble,
And that is a man in a thouſand.
Tol lol de rol.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Pleaſant enough, on our march from Windſor, Lenox ſlipping a note into my hand, the inſtant I gave him one; but what ſays his. (reads) Dear Sinclair, ſoon as off guard, walk into the park, I want to ſpeak with you on particular buſineſs.—Almoſt the very words of mine to him; he's my friend; I'll aſk his advice before I determine to marry Mary. Determine! oh, my heart!

lg.l: When night, and left upon my guard,
Nor whiſp'ring breeze, nor leaf is heard,
And ſtars between cloſe branches peep,
And birds are huſh'd in downy ſleep,
My ſoul to ſofteſt thoughts reſign'd,
And lovely Mary, fills my mind.
At every noiſe, for bluff "Who's there!"
I gently breathe, "is't thou, my fair?
Thy dying ſoldier haſte and ſee,
Oh come, ſweet Mary, come to me."
As on my poſt, thro' blaze of day,
The wretched, happy, ſad and gay
In quick ſucceſſion move along,
I ſee, nor hear the paſſing throng;
My ſoul ſo wrapt in Mary's charms,
I hug my muſket in my arms.
So, all of paſſion, joy and grief,
When comrades bring the glad relief,
I cry thy ſoldier, haſte and ſee,
Oh come, ſweet Mary, come to me!

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: "I've a great deal to ſay to you"—and I've a great deal to ſay to him—Oh! he's here—Well, Sinclair, what's this affair?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Nay, what's your's with me?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Come, you tell firſt.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: No, no; you lets hear.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Not a word from me till you—

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: I'm determin'd that you ſhall—come I'll not ſpeak'till—

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Now I beg you'll—

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Then you muſt know, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Why, we're like people in the ſtreet giving each other the way; but here I ſtop, and now you paſs on.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Then, Ned, of all the girls in our town, to me there's none like Mary Tactic.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Why, I think ſhe's a moſt charming pretty ſoul.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Ay, but I love her.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: I know I love her.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Oh, you muſt miſtake; its I that adore her.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Upon my word you're wrong; for I'm the man that wou'd die for her.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: That's as much as to ſay you'd fight for her.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Any man but you.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Why, Lenox, I ſhou'dn't like to fight you.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: But any other, I didn't mind how great;—Ay, damme, even the corporal.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Any fellow that dar'd to think of Mary.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Do you call me fellow, Jack?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Yes, you're a good fellow.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Was it to tell me that you loved Mary Tactic, that you deſired me to meet you?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Was your only buſineſs but to let me know you lov'd her?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: LENOX.
sp.l: I like each girl that I come near
Tho' none I love but Mary;
Oh, ſhe's my darling, only dear
Bewitching little fairy.
I aſk a kiſs, and ſhe looks down,
Her cheeks are ſpread with bluſhes,
By Jove, ſays I, I'll take the town,
Me back ſhe gently puſhes—
I like each girl, &c.

sp.speaker: SINCLAIR.
sp.l: When off 'twas blown, and 'twas my place
To fly for Mary's bonnet,
So charming look'd her lovely face,
There I ſtood gazing on it.
Dreſs'd all in white ſhe tripp'd from home,
And ſet my blood a thrilling,
O, zounds! ſays I, the French are come,
Sweet Mary look'd ſo killing.
I like each girl, &c.

sp.speaker: LENOX.
sp.l: When to our Colonel at review
A Dutcheſs cried, ſo airy!
"How does your Royal Highneſs do?"
Says I, "I thank you, Mary."

sp.speaker: SINCLAIR.
sp.l: To quick time, marching to'ther day,
Our fiſes play'd Andrew Cary,
To every girl I gave the way,
In compliment to Mary.
I like each girl, &c.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: I've a greater regard for you than for all the men in our regiment put together.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p:
I always thought you my friend, and
I'm certain I'm your's—Let us leave it to Mary's own choice.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Why, true; it's a pity to teize a young woman that can never love one.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: And it's fooliſh and ill-natured to ſtand in the way of another man's happineſs, when we can't forward our own by it.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes; let's aſk her in downright Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Done.

lg.l: Oh, come away,
Come, my ſoldier bonny;
I am ſmart and gay,
But for handſome Johnny.
Enſign pretty doll,
Crimſon ſaſh ſo wrapt in;
Minces, "charming Poll,
"Can you love a Captain?"
Oh, come away, &c.
To his fine Marque,
At the camp, laſt ſummer,
He ſent for me to tea,
By the little drummer.
Oh, come away, &c.
As I croſs parade,
Officers ſtand blinking;
Under each cockade,
Sly, an eye cocks winking.
Oh, come away, amp;c.
Johnny ſteps in time,
Sweetly play the hautboys;
Hearts all merry chime,
March, and beat the foe, boys.
Oh, come away, &c.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, Sinclair, did you ſee my father? Is that Lenox?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Aſk her.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: No, do you?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Mary, you know very well, that I think you a moſt charming girl.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Well, that's no fault of mine.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: No, its no fault—for to be ſure you can't help being the ſweeteſt ſoul—you're ſure Mary, I love you; but here's Jack Sinclair ſays he does.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh yes; he told me ſo.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Well; but didn't I tell you I loved you?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Well, and if you do, you can't help that, you know.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: We don't want to quarrel, becauſe that woudn't be friendly.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: No; 'twou'dn't be like brother ſoldiers; ſo, yourſelf confeſs which of us you love.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Ay, do, Mary, your word ſhall decide it.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Which of you I love! Upon my honor that's very conceited of you both—a pretty decent ſort of confeſſion too for a girl to make; but certainly was I to marry, I muſt chuſe only one.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Ah, but, Mary, wou'd you chuſe one of us?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Indeed I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Sweet girl, but which?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Ay, which, Mary?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Well, I will own it, if you'll both promiſe not go fight ſword and piſtol up in Hyde-Park, as the officers do.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: If you chuſe Ned Lenox, may I be whipp'd if I wiſh him the leaſt ill-will.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: And, my lovely Mary, if you prefer Jack Sinclair to me, if I ever bear him a grudge for it, may I be drum'd out of the regiment.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Heigho! it's a ſevere taſk, but—

sp.l: When in a garden ſweet, I walk,
The charming flowers admiring,
Each nods upon its tender ſtalk,
And ſeems my touch deſiring.
Tho' all of beauties are poſſeſs'd,
Too much to be rejected,
Yet only one, for Mary's breaſt,
By fancy is ſelected.
Full conſcious of thy faith and truth,
No wrong to thee intended.
Ah! ſhould I chuſe ſome other youth,
Be not, fond youth, offended.
The ſtarting tear, the heaving ſigh,
True ſigns, not diſregarded;
But, by a maid, more fair than I,
Oh, be thy love rewarded.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: My dear fellow, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Was it any thing elſe but Mary, I cou'd—poor Lenox!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Ah, boys! Jack Sinclair, Ned Lenox, come from duty at Windſor—Rare changes ſince you've been laſt on the parade!

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: The roll-call.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.l: Tap beats the dub upon my aching heart,

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.l: Sad ſtrikes the ſound that bids me hence depart;

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.l: Ah! can I from you ſtay?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.l: One kiſs and then away.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Go to your duty, go.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Is that to muſter the men? For what?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: For what! Why, to draught out a detachment for Holland.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: And do Sinclair and Lenox go?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: To be ſure, if ſo their lot be.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh heavens!

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Mary! Ay, off to the parade! I ſee my daughter will have a ſoldier, but ſhe can't have a better man—you, ſir, run after that girl.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: I'm a married man; and mus'nt run after the girls.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: What, then you're married?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; and ſo is my wife, a poor woman, ſir—I'm not yet worth quite a plumb, might have made my fortune by marriage, I have had my opportunities among the dear creatures.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: There was a fine old maiden,
Prim, ſlim, and ſhe wore a muff;
Rich flower'd ſilks array'd in,
She went to church, and ſhe there—took ſnuff.
In love not to flinch,
I aſk'd for a pinch;
Says I, fine rappee,
Says ſhe, he, he, he.
She'd five grey hairs,
A kiſs miſs if you pleaſe,
I happen'd to ſneeze,
Then in her airs,
So highly provok'd,
Tho' her cat I ſtroak'd,
Loud rattled her tongue,
For her man ſhe rung,
And I was ordered to walk down ſtairs.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: A grand buxom widow bonny,
Fat, ſquat, but lord what o'that,
She had a pow'r of money,
But no parrot, nor dog, nor cat.
Watch, trinket, and ſeals,
And rings to her nails,
And before ſhe'd dine,
A glaſs of tent wine,
She got ſo gay,
She ſung, I bore bob,
And jingled hob nob;
But one curs'd day,
A Captain from Cork,
Spoil'd all my love work;
He gave, her a ſmack,
He gave me a whack,
She choſe the Captain, and I walk'd away.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Romping miſs at boarding ſchool,
Shuttle cock play and ſwing ſo high;
Needle wasn't her working tool,
But knew how to make a nice dirt pye:
She con'd ſugar crib.
And then tell a fib,
On poney cou'd ſtraddle,
Nor bridle not ſaddle,
She gallop'd well,
She cou'd jump down ſtairs,
And whiſtle her prayers,
But cou'd not ſpell;
In ſilk ſhoes, ſlip ſtood,
The minuet trod,
She ſqualled, parlevoud,
And ſwore I was rude;
I was kick'd out by her Ma'amoiſelle.

sp.p: I'll ſee if his majorſhip won't ſtand a glaſs of ſtout punch (aſide.) Sir, I want to go abroad.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Becauſe, then I ſha'n't be at home—I've left my wife there.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Why, death and ounds! at Dorking in Surry.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Swear ſo, you raſcal!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: To ſhew you I'm fit for a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: But what are you now?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p:
Nothing; tho' I was every thing—an Auction-porter, Watchman, Town-crier, Monmouth-ſtreet Pluck-em-in, Playhouſe Conſtable, Dog-ſtealer—High and Low-life, ſir, from Guard of a Stage-coach, to Waiter in a Cyder-cellar—my days have been a round of "paſt ten o'clock"—"juſt a going"—"nobody bid more"—"oh yes, this is to give notice"—"pray
walk in"—"handſome ſuit of clothes, fit you nicely"—"take care of your pockets"— (whiſtles) "here, boy!—poor fellow! Ponto, Ponto"—"your pint, ſir—champaign, cackagay!"

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: So then, friend, you've come off from your wife to turn ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Why, ſir, ſhe vex'd me up into ſuch a paſſion, that I muſt beat ſomebody; ſo I thought it more honorable to flog the enemies of my country, than the wife of my boſom.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: But how did ſhe vex you?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Sir, I love a drop of ale—'t'other day, we had a mug—ſhe puts it to her head; "my dear," ſays I, "s;top, the devil is painted at the bottom, and 'twill frighten you if you look on't"—ſays ſhe "I defy the devil and all his works," and up ſhe puts it—"hold, my love," ſays I, "you're a bit of a democrat, and it's his Majeſty that's painted at the bottom" —"no," ſays ſhe, "I'm a loyal ſubject, and I long to ſee the King's ſweet face"—ſo, again, up went the jug, and the devil a drop ſhe left me in it.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! what's your name.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Nipperkin.—Mr. Nipperkin, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Nipperkin, we'll ſee if we can't make a ſoldier of you.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Oh, ſir, that's as eaſy as making an attorney a rogue, or make this a ſtrong arm, when its already at hand—make a ſoldier! hem! ſir, you do the exerciſe capital I ſuppoſe, he, he, he! ſhew us a bit—wheel! to the right! ſtop, ſir, till I chalk your arm.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Why, do you think I don't know my right from my left?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: do you? (gravely) huzza! the ſerjeant major knows his right hand from his left—

sp.speaker: Major.
sp.p: Why, you dog, are you humming me?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.l: March! before great Juſtice Laro.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: Death and ounds! am I arreſted?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.l: Sblood! don't fear, my little hero,
'Tis only to be atteſted.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: Oh I what then, I muſt take an oath?
Here goes; I ſwear by Jingo,
I'll not turn ſoldier, till we both
Together tipple ſtingo.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.l: With all my heart,
We'll take a quart.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: Or bowl of punch.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: That's better.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: But firſt a ſlice
Of ham ſo nice,
For I approve a whetter.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: For I approve a Whetter.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.l: You have but to ſail o'er to Holland d'ye ſee,
And the French kick back into their nation;
Then the Emperor, Stadtholder, Pope, you and me,
Will ſit down to a jolly-fication.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: I'm tir'd of kiſſing old Judy, my wife,
I muſt have a pair of new lips,
So, when I'm in Holland, upon my life,
I'll be at their fine Dutch tulips.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Then you have but to ſail, &c.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Parade in St. James's Park.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: No, I can't ſee any one to give me a true account how they've gone on.
Oh, well, Lenox, and how? ay, tell us.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: My unlucky fate! curſed chance.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! then you are one of them that's draughted to go abroad in all theſe dangers.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: And, Mary, do you think its that, that cou'd have vex'd me ſo? I ſee what a mean opinion you have of me—I now don't wonder at your prefering Jack Sinclair to me—you think I'm a cowardly poltroon, that wou'd rather ſtay at home in idleneſs, than go out to fight the battles for my King and Country.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: No indeed, Lenox: I know you've a very good ſpirit—I didn't mean to diſparage you; but I tremble to think of the dreadful ſlaughter thoſe poor fellows may be expoſed to.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Dreadful! Isn't it glory?

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Aſpiring thoughts my breaſt expand,
Ah! why to me is given a ſoul,
Proudly impatient of command,
Yet doom'd by fate to bear controul;
Oft at the haughty ſerjeant's will,
A poor recruit, thro' chilling morn,
I've ſtood for hours the tedious drill,
Sad object of his blows and ſcorn.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Nor ſunk my youthfull ſpirits then,
Tho' fierce he poiz'd the dread rattan,
I thus, when taught to conquer men,
Suppreſs'd the feelings of a man;
And now the harveſts warring pride,
When Engliſh triumph, French men yield,
A uſeleſs tool I'm thrown aſide,
Whilſt others reap the glorious field.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Oh, my Polly! we muſt part.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: The lot is caſt, and I'm call'd away—I muſt leave you.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: And can you? Oh my love!

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: What then, you go? you have the upper hand of me in every thing. I muſt ſneak about here in the park, like a watchman—my marches from ſtory's gate to the ſtable yard, and all my war's, with the old women to take off their pattens; whilſt you, led on by your Prince—I ſhall go diſtracted!

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: You've little cauſe to envy me—reflect, I leave Mary, I leave her with you too—my rival—with you, that love, that deſerve her ſo much better than myſelf.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Not 'liſt, you raſcal! after ſwallowing a bowl of punch?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: My dear ſir, don't be in a paſſion—I have my reaſons for both.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Your reaſons, you raſcal—

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Death and ounds, ſir, don't ſwear—but my reaſon's I wou'dn't turn ſoldier, becauſe I hate fighting; and I drank up the punch, becauſe I love drinking, that ſhews that I'm both a ſafe and a good companion.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: You're an arch raſcal, and I don't know what to make of you?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Then I'll tell you what you'd beſt do, ſir.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Giye me another bowl, ſir, and let me alone.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Come, Sinclair, quick—you've but little time to prepare your knapſack.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Dear father, muſt he go?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: To be ſure.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Oh, certainly: he muſt go and protect us all. Egad, I'm like a miniſter of ſtate; whilſt I ſit at peace at home over my bottle, I ſend another man out to fight, that I may enjoy it in comfort.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p:
Mary, Sinclair and Lenox are honeſt lads—I know they both love you; but as the miſery or happineſs of marriage will chiefly affect you, I leave the choice of a huſband entirely to yourſelf, my girl. If Lenox is the man, love favours him; but if Sinclair, what he loſes in
love, he muſt make up in honor—give him a kiſs, and a few of my beſt ruffled ſhirts; and drop a tear, and that affair's ſettled.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Farewell (to Lenox) adieu!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! my heart will break! deareſt father, can't you get him off?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Child, I wiſh him too well even to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Jack, don't think me a worthleſs fellow, tho' I am ſhov'd aſide, and you choſen for the poſt of honor—'tis only blind fortune has done it; for had ſhe fix'd on me,—

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: No bouncing! indeed, I myſelf once took a French colonel by the noſe—To be ſure, at the time, I flouriſhed one of Sharp's beſt patent concaves.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: My love, beſides your conſtancy, I rely on the generoſity of Lenox; in my abſence, don't avoid him; it will be my only comfort to reflect, that I have in England a faithful ſweetheart, and a true friend.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Hem; (ſings)"My Poll and my Partner Joe."
sp.stage: (looks archly and ſignificantly at Lenox and Mary.)

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: I don't know what you are; but you, are a very impudent fellow.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: There you fib, for you know I'm a very impudent fellow. Drum without. Rub-a-dub, boys, hey, for Holland!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Dear youth, keep this for Mary's ſake;

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.l: Sweet maid this poor remembrance take;
When rivals tender things ſhall ſay,
Oh, look on that and turn away!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Should rivals win thy witching ſmile,
Think what thy Mary feels the while.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.l: When bullets whiſtle in the wind,
My only fear,
My only dear,
Is for my treaſure left behind,

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: 'Midſt warring fields may angels come,
And o'er thy head
Their pinions ſpread,
Then bring my love in ſafety home.
sp.stage: Enter Officers, Soldiers, &c. as prepared for the March—A Variety of other Characters taking Leave.

sp.speaker: GRAND CHORUS.
sp.l: Our Gracious George, and Charlotte's Son,
'Tis Royal Frederic leads us on.

sp.speaker: WOMEN.
sp.l: Britannia fell a ſhower of piteous tears
To ſee, (alas!) an hapleſs Monarch bleed;
The Royal Widow's mournful plaint ſhe hears,
And bids her gen'rous ſons revenge the cruel deed.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: To arms, ſhe cries, to ſave, is now the word,
And 'tis the hand of Mercy draws the ſword.
Our Gracious George, and Charlette's Son,
Tis Royal Frederic leads us on.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Every circumſtance turns out ſo contrary to what might have made my friend Sinclair happy, and perhaps baniſh for a time the thoughts of Mary from my mind. Since I've no place in Mary's affections, what's in England worth a thought?—I burn I'm mad with deſire to follow my Prince.—But to be left ſtuck up here like a lamp-poſt, with an uſeleſs muſket in my hand—I've a mind to put it to uſe— (placing it to his head)—but my life's not my own—my country yet may want it.—For all Sinclair bid me ſee Mary, what now muſt he feel, on the reflection that he's left her behind with me?—Tho' I ſcorn to take advantage of his abſence—I'll avoid the ſight of her.

lg.l: A maid I love who loves not me,
Yet to my friend is kind;
But thus I'll let my charmer ſee,
I'm to my fate reſign'd.
To means as delicate as new,
Ideas ſoft aſcend;
To ſhew myſelf a lover true,
I'll be a lover's friend.
Beat, gentle love and friendſhip ſweet,
In uniſon divine;
In Sinclair ſtill a friend I'll meet,
And Mary ſtill is mine.
Burn, gen'rous flame, within my breaſt,
Still conſtant, bright, and pure;
Ah! let me ſee another bleſt,
And ſtill my pains endure.
Each ſelfiſh thought, my mind above,
Be theſe my joys alone,
The happineſs of thoſe I love
Prefering to my own.
Beat, gentle love, &c.

div.stage: Enter NIPPERKIN, drunk, with a ſmall Keg, ſinging.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Tol, lol, lol!—Now, if I can get out thro' this ſame Buckingham Gate—

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Brandy— (holding up the keg.)

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: You'd better give an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: To me.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Your queſtion?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: I aſk'd who went there.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p:
Then you aſk'd a very ſilly queſtion,
when you might ſee it was a brave boy—Huzza!—the town's our own!

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Damn your trifling! Give, this inſtant, a proper anſwer, or I'll fire— (preſenting.)

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Hold! Zounds, be quiet.—Is that your politeneſs?—Juſt under the very noſe of the Court?—Fire! and wake the maids of honour—ſweet creatures!—that may now be dreaming of the lords in waiting, and white rod, and gold ſtick, and ſuch other grand affairs.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: I'm in no jeſting humour—Quick, ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: 'Sblood! are you deaf?—I'm ſpeaking as quick as I can—Stop!—your firing will be petty-treaſon—our Gracious Sovereign may be at this moment in a ſweet dream, that one of her beloved ſons, her gallant Frederick, is returning crown'd • ith Laurels.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: And I no hand in placing them on his brow!—By heavens I'll not ſtay—I'll follow the detachment, tho' they ſhoot me for a deſerter—Hold!—this fellow may—why, it's Nipperkin— (looking.)

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Didn't I tell you it was a brave boy; yet you wou'dn't believe me, and be damn'd to you!—after getting ſo nobly drunk, to frighten me back into ſobriety! and ſo I've now all to do over again.—Why, dam'me, you don't mind what trouble you give a poor man— (knocks with his knuckles againſt the keg)—Are you within?—Very well—I'll be with you, or you ſhall be with me.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Where were you going?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: To the college—my father is a Chelſea penſioner; and about once a quarter, like a dutiful ſon, I bring the honeſt gentleman a little brandy and tobacco, and ſuch other nice dainties, to comfort his old ſoul—Oh, Lenox!

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: You're right to be kind to your father—Give me your coat.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: "kind to my father!"—"Give me your coat!"—That's very odd talk at this time of night.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: You take this—Quick!— (They change cloaths.)

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: I fancy I look better in the King's coat than the King wou'd look in mine— (ſtruts about.)

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Give me your hat.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Sir, take your's off the block— (pointing to Lenox's head, and bowing.)

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: —There; now ſtand you in my place.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Did ever I think I ſhou'd have a place at Court?—"Who goes there?"— (preſents at Lenox)—Speak, or, dam'me, I'll fire!—I'm in no jeſting humour—talk! or I'll blow your brains over the canal, thro' the Horſe-Guards, croſs the way to Whitehall, into the lottery-wheels.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Silence! (aſide.) The royal and affectionate parents ſend a darling ſon to face the perils of war, aſſert his country's honour!—What Engliſhman wou'dn't follow the illuſtrious example—Huſh! not a word.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p:
Now that fellow's gone to commit a robbery in my coat, and I ſhall get hang'd for it: The gate's ſhut, and I can't get put to give
my poor father his drop—Then I muſt give it to his poor ſon— (takes up the keg and drinks)—I'll ſmoke a pipe too— (ſits on the keg)—Well, he didn't take my match, and my bottle of phoſphorus— (takes out a pipe, fills, lights, ſits on the keg and ſmokes.)—If my wife was here now, I ſhou'dn't have all this ſport to myſelf— (riſes, takes up the keg and drinks)—my chair produces good table drink.

lg.l: A glaſs is good, and a laſs is good,
And a pipe to ſmoke in cold weather;
The world is good, and the people are good.
And we're all good fellows together.
A bottle it is a very good thing,
With a good deal of good wine in it;
A ſong is good, when a body can ſing,
And to finiſh, we muſt begin it.
A table is good, when ſpread with good chear,
And good company ſitting round it;
When a good way off, we're not very near,
And for ſorrow the devil confound it.
A glaſs is good, &c,
A friend is good, when you're out of good luck,
For that's a good time to try him;
For a Juſtice good, the haunch of a buck,
With ſuch a good preſent you buy him.
A fine old woman is good when ſhe's dead,
A rogue very good for good hanging;
A fool is good, by the noſe to be led,
My good ſong deſerves a good banging.
A glaſs is good, &c

div.p: But it's getting cool here, il freſco. I'll ſtep into my parlour— (takes up the keg, and goes into the centry-box, ſits and falls aſleep.)

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: As my dear lover ſaid, there can't be the leaſt danger in paying ſome attention to poor Lenox whilſt he's away.—He took on ſo at my refuſing him, and the loſs of his comrade, that I know he hasn't eat a morſel this bleſſed day. He has a tender and an honeſt heart, and ſure no harm for me to try if I can comfort him.—The Park's got ſo ſtill, he may eat and drink fome'at, as I'm ſure he wo'nt come to me when he's reliev'd.—Lenox!— (goes towards the box, calling ſoftly)—Oh! my heavens! if he isn't fallen aſleep, and here's the corporal coming!— (looking down the walk)—If he's caught ſo—Lenox!— (calls.)

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: —"Take care of your pockets."

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Get up.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: "Paſt four o'clock!"

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Sure he's been drinking to drive away his ſorrows. Riſe! Here's the guards!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Pray walk in, ſir—I've a pretty coat will juſt fit you.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Eh! Sleep on your poſt! Halloa! Centry! Here'll be rare flogging work; take his arms! drag him up!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Fine cloudy morning!

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Ay, dam'me, it will be a fine cloudy morning with you, peeping through the iron bars.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Corporal—

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Is that Miſs Mary Tactic?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: You know Lenox is a good ſoldier, and ſhould be excuſed if he's a bit overtaken, conſider, taking leave of his comrades; you know he's ſo well belov'd, and ſuch a temptation—then his ſpirits in ſuch a ſtate, a very little liquor might have intoxicated—

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: —That dogſkin will make a pair of pumps.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: My ſkin!—You'll ſee what the drummer will make of your dogſkin.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Pray, don't inform the commanding officer.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Why, Miſs Mary, you know it's not in my power to ſave him, if, as you ſay, he's brought to court-martial for this.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: His royal highneſs is good and merciful;—I'm ſure he'd conſider ſo excellent a ſoldier as Lenox—Now, do let the poor fellow come to his ſenſes, and ſay nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: But then I ſhou'd be puniſhed myſelf, Miſs—Muſt give him up—Take him to the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
Unhappy creature!—and yet I'm aſhamed of Lenox.—However, I'll make my
father uſe all his intereſt for his pardon.—How have I been deceived in him! and how fortunate that my heart wasn't caught by his kind and obliging manners.—He loved me—he is Sinclair's friend, and therefore has a right to my aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Why, he wou'd ſtand a better chance of mercy from his royal highneſs—his ſentence here might be death.—I'll pretend not to know but he's one of the draughts that has ſtaid behind; and to colour it, I'll neither ſee nor talk to him; but at day-break, a guard ſhall take him to Greenwich time enough before the men embark.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.l: Rare rattling boys, don't let your pris'ner go I deſire, For ſuddling ſouls, the Savoy—ho!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: I'm Captain Muz.—(All.) Are yon ſo?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.l: Hark ye, 'ſqire!
1. I'm Fifer Bob,
2. I'm Drummer Dob,
3. I'm Natty Jack,
4. I'm Paddy Whack,
5. I'm Darby Drill,
6. I'm Roving Will,
7. I'm Nimble Nick,
8. I'm a good Stick,
9. I'm Devil Dick.
—Zounds! what's your name?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.l: "Paſt four o'clock!"— (All.) We'll make you tame!
S'blood and fire!
Drink, ſoldiers, drink, and bear no blame.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter LENOX in NIPPERKIN's Cloaths, and Capt. CRUIZER.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No ſuch thing, friend.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Do, dear, good, worthy ſir, let me go on board your tender.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But for what?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: To partake of the glorious expedition of my comrades.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your comrades!—Ay, what, are you a ſoldier?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: —Yes—ſir—no—I am—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: if a ſoldier, and not one of the drafted men, what brings you to Greenwich? and if you belong to the detachment, why out of your regimentals, and not with your corps?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Sir, I am, as yet, only in wiſh a ſoldier—I ſaid "my comrades," becauſe I'm acquainted with a number of the men; and I've conceived ſuch a friendſhip for ſome of the honeſt ſellows, that I can't turn my head to any buſineſs, with the grief of being ſeparated from them—only let me go, and you'll ſee how I'll fight.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But do you know the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p:
Humanity.—To ſtop the ravages of war abroad, ſecure the bleſſings of peace, commerce, plenty and happineſs at home to Old England, where a good king is the common
parent—every man captain of his caſtle, and the laws to protect his property, wife and children. Frenchmen give Britons freedom!—But huzza!—we'll pluck Sprigs of Laurel from their Tree of Liberty.

lg.l: The goddeſs of mountains, blythe, roſy and free,
As the airs that flew round her, had once a fair tree;
'Twas Liberty call'd, and a fav'rite of Jove,
And ſweet was the fruit to the bright queen of Love;
In Albion 'twas planted, its branches ſpread wide.
Of her ſons and her daughters the glory and pride.
Tranquil pleaſures,
Softeſt meaſures,
Then lead the dance, and give Britons to ſing,
Loving, loyal,
Good and royal,
A people happy, and honour'd their king.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Our ſly gallic neighbours peep'd into our grounds,
And fain would have ſcal'd the white wall that ſurrounds,
They long'd for our tree, when its beauties were known,
But miſſing their aim, would have one of their own;
For this, in poor France, a vile bramble takes root,
Each leaf is a poniard, and bitter the fruit.
Pity ſleeping,
Angels weeping,
Saw the fierce ſavage triumph o'er men;
Juſtice firing,
All inſpiring,
To drive the tyger back into his den.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, my lad, I muſt ſay I admire your ſpirit, and I'm ſorry we can't take you; but undiſciplin'd recruits won't do.—The nature of the ſervice we're order'd on, requires pick'd men.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: There's a boat now going off—By heavens I will get aboard.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By heavens you ſhall not tho'—Holloa!—Stop that fellow—keep him out of the boat.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: Sir, his Royal Highneſs's aid-du-camp wou'd ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I come.— (Exit Serjeant.)—Something in this young fellow that ſtrikes me exceedingly— (looks out)—No—the boat's gone without him, and there he walks melancholy away; and intimate with the ſoldiers!—Might perhaps have given me ſome clue to diſcover my ſon—I begin now to deſpair; for if my boy is ſtill in any of thoſe regiments, he muſt have chang'd his name.

sp.speaker: Serjeant.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh, true.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: The coming ſpring begins to make the country look delightful—The ſweeteſt ſeaſon approaching, that even the birds join in love—and my love to leave me!

sp.l: Sing, charming warblen! voice of love!
The dulcet ſong
Now pours along,
For love can harmonize the grove,
Bid balmy zephyrs gently bear
The liquid notes thro' yielding air.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thoſe men loiter along the road— (looks out.)

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, your honour, I hope his Highneſs isn't yet gone over to the ſhip!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Eh! What, my laſs, do you, too, want to go and pull Sprigs of Laurel?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: No, ſir;—but it's about a young man, a ſoldier—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The devil's in the ſoldiers for bringing the women after them.—You're a modeſt, pretty looking thing—you fooliſh jade, what buſineſs have you with the young men?—Take your ſnivelling good bye on ſhore—no petticoats come on board my ſhip.—I adviſe you, child, to modeſty and diſcretion; for your own forwardneſs and folly contribute as often to the ruin of innocents, as the baſe arts of villainous ſeduction.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p:
I believe that gentleman means well; but he ſhou'd have known who he was talking to—and even then, ſweet and welcome is the gentle monitor; for what we liſten to with pleaſure,
we follow with delight.—I may chance to ſee my Sinclair again before he goes—I know he'll conquer; and when he returns—Oh! ſuch a garland as I'll make him!—Aye, and he ſhall wear it too.

lg.l: Fragrant chaplets quaintly twining.
Thro' the ſingers of the fair;
Ev'ry grace and ſweet combining,
For the ſoldier's brow prepare.
Gift of Venus, bluſhing, glowing,
Let the lovely roſe be ſeen;
And the Laurel, Mars beſlowing,
Make the wreath an evergreen.

sp.p: Oh! Lud!—if here isn't Sinclair and my • ather.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Zounds! how often will they halt?—Sinclair! Why do you run before the rank?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Don't you ſee my attraction?—Oh! my love!—(embraces Mary.)

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Mary!—Now, girl, what has bewitched you to follow us?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: My lovely, faithful ſoul! don't be angry with her.

lg.l: Parted from thee, my ev'ry bliſs,
My only joy, the parting kiſs;
So ſweet! and yet ſo ſcant a ſtore,
I languiſh'd to return for more.
And in thou come, and doſt thou bring
The ſource whence thouſand raptures ſpring?
Oh! let me preſs thoſe lips again,
Thus parting, ever thus remain.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! I've ſomething to tell you about Lenox—he is— (drum, fife, muſic, and ſhouts without)

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: The men on their march—Get you out of their way, child—you'll ſee us at Greenwich.—(Shouts without.)

div.stage: Enter Officers, Soldiers, &c. accompanied and followed by a number of People. All croſs with ſhouting, drums, and martial muſic.

lg.l: Sound trumpets! hard taſks to a ſoldier belong,
'Midſt dreadful alarms,
The man to deſtroy who has done him no wrong,
Thus ſounding to arms.
Hoarſe echo brawls to the loud double drum,
With come to fate come;
Let juſtice the ſoldiers bold quarrel ordain,
Tho' dyed all in blood he's yet free from a ſtain;
Then the battle not ceaſe,
'Tis for glory for peace.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Sinclair and Tactic.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Oh ſir, I've a dreadful boding of Mary's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Something about Lenox.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: I ſee it—he's been baſe and treacherous; and for all that, he ſeemingly reſigned her: no ſooner was my back turned, than he has dared to renew his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Plague of your nonſenſical love and jealouſy—mind your duty—run on and fall into your rank (puſhes him off) with their ſweethearts and friends, and ſtuff! I wiſh we had them all ſafe on board—ſome reaſons tho' in Sinclair's ſuſpicions! I had a good opinion of Lenox—but this violent friendſhip of your young ſolks, all a feather—give me an old friend.

lg.l: Midſt flaunting ſhrubs in vernal green,
Each ſiner than his fellow,
A venerable oak I've ſeen,
Well clad in ſober yellow.
Whilſt wint'ry winds cou'd blow around,
Their leaves all helter-ſkelter,
Poor birds within his branches found,
An hoſpitable ſhelter.
In life's gay ſpring too oft' we find
The buds of ſoft affection,
Scarce knit, when blown by ev'ry wind,
In this and that direction.
Oh, come, thou friend, that can'ſt endure,
The ſhocks of rougheſt weather;
Frank, chearful, honeſt and mature,
Well lire; ay, die together.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Before Greenwich Hoſpital—View of the Thames—Tender at anchor and boats with ſoldiers croſſing to it.
Enter George Streamer, attended ty eight men-of-wars men, with their ears.

sp.speaker: Streamer.
sp.p: Chearly my boys, clear the gangway there! here's another boatfull—we'll bring you gentlemen of the red cloth along-ſide of the Frenchmen; I hope 'twill ſoon be our turn to take a ſpell at that work. We have a Prince too to lead us on—oh dam'me! how I long to powder their toupees.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: I'm here or there a jolly dog,
At land or ſea, I'm all a-gog,
To fight or kiſs or touch the grog,
For I'm a jovial midſhipman,
A ſmart young midſhipman,
A little midſhipman,
To fight or kiſs or touch the grog,
Oh! I'm a jovial midſhipman.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: My honour's free from ſtain or ſpeck,
The foremaſt-men are at my beck,
With pride I walk the quarter-deck, (takes off his hat)
For I'm a ſmart young midſhipman, &c.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: I mix the pudding for our meſs,
In uniform then neatly dreſs;
The captain aſks, (no need to preſs,)
Come, dine with me, young midſhipsman, &c.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: When Royal William comes on board,
By England's Navy, all, ador'd,
From him, I ſometimes paſs the word,
Tho' I'm an humble midſhipman, &c.

div.stage: Exeunt with ſailors &c. into the boat.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Lenox in this curſed hobble?—Art ugly job, faith!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Father, won't you make the Duke forgive him?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: I make Dukes forgive People! what does the girl take me for?

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: My beloved Mary, tell me this affair that brought you? ay, well, as I was gone, Lenox—

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh! he is—

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: A villain!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Be quiet—you wrong'd him in the love buſineſs—egad, poor Lenox has ſomething elſe now to think of! Oh, yes, he'll be ſhot.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Who! ſir! Mary, what has he done?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Is it poſſible! I had no idea that his life was in danger.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: What's his crime, and where is he now?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: He has ſlept on his guard, and he is now in irons at the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bring him along, an obſtinate young ſcoundrel!

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: What's the matter, ſir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
A blockhead that I've refuſed to take on board, jumps into the river, ſwims over to the ſhip; and there he's been found hiding himſelf
behind a hen-coop. A brave fellow—but we ſhou'd frighten him a little.
sp.stage: Enter LENOX, in cuſtody of ſoldiers and ſailors.
sp.p: So, you wou'dn't take my word for it; but now you ſhall give an account of yourſelf before his Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Why, it's Lenox?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: One of the guards, ſir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Indeed! hold him in cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Ah! Sinclair, doesn't your heart bleed for your unhappy friend?

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Why, how the devil did you ſhake off your irons and eſcape from the Savoy?

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Major, I never was diſgrac'd with irons, or in a jail.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Zounds! Mary, what ſtory's this you've been telling us? Oh! I ſee it's all a ſlam, an excuſe for her coming after us to Greenwich, and taking another parting kiſs with your ſweetheart.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Indeed, father, I don't know what you mean; Lenox now, has got other cloaths on—but I'm ſure I ſaw him taken into cuſtody, priſoner by the Corporal—Think me— (ſobs) ſo—artful—as—to—invent ſtories—only—to—compaſs—my—own—pleaſure! (ſobs)

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Nay, my love, don't weep—your father cannot ſuppoſe—

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Mary, to oblige you, I've ordered Lenox to be brought before the Duke himſelf—oh! yonder they bring him.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Why, corporal, you're drunk too;—here they've brought him already.

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: I drunk! let me tell you, Major, I can be as ſober on my duty, as any man.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Why, did you pull him from behind the hen-coop?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: Hen-coop! Oh! you have been taking your drops! I ſay, I found Lenox on his guard moſt damnably diſguiſed.

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Well, you may find him there, diſguis'd (points to Lenox.)

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: You found me drunk! why, corporal, what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Corp.
sp.p: 'Tis Lenox! then who the devil have we got pris'ner yonder!

sp.speaker: Nipperkin.
sp.p: "Paſt four o'clock!"

sp.speaker: Tactic.
sp.p: Why, it's the joking raſcal, who cajol'd me out of the bowl of punch.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Nipperkin! Oh! I ſee how this has been.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: I'll have juſtice—they took my keg. (looks at Lenox) What, then you have been doing it? I thought ſo—and taken—I deſire he mayn't be hang'd in my coat.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
(To Lenox) Young man, I've laid your caſe before his Royal Highneſs—tho' your quiting your poſt was a crime, that demands from military diſcipline, a ſevere puniſhment; yet, in
conſideration of your laudable motive, a brilliant example of noble ardour for your country's honor, he not only pardons you, but from your high character as an excellent ſoldier, preſents you with this purſe.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: A purſe for only ſwimming to—by the lord, I once ſwam from Chelſea-reach to Batterſea bridge—give me.—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nipperkin! why, who made a ſoldier of you? here, my lad! (offering the purſe)

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: A hen-coop! zounds to ſmuggie myſelf into a fight I'd hide behind a mouſe trap.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: I humbly thank his Highneſs—pardon is the utmoſt grace I cou'd hope for—my friend (to Sinclair) you have never diſobeyed orders—a more finiſhed ſoldier, on the eve of being married too—and the Prince's bounty will be applied to a better purpoſe in contributing additional comforts to an amiable woman. (gives purſe to Sinclair.)

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Zounds! they won't let me be generous—nobody'll give me purſes to give away to poor families.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Sir, if I am only ſuffered but to go with my Prince, ſome future event may offer an occaſion, really to ſignalize myſelf, and by merit win a reward, of which, I am now totally unworthy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A liberal minded fellow, faith! ſo, my laſs, this your ſoldier laddie!

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Oh, no, ſir—I grant he deſerves—ay, the moſt beautiful lady—but here's my humble choice.

sp.speaker: Sinclair.
sp.p: Humble, indeed! yet I have reaſon to be proud with the friendſhip of Lenox, and the love of Mary.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Captain, lend me a guinea, I'll tell you a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You drunken ſcoundrel, I'll break your head.

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Well, I'can't return the compliment till you get one to break, (aſide) This boy's generoſity has ſo wrought upon my heart, that I can't bear he ſhould longer remain in this obſcure wretchedneſs—hearky (to Lenox) down on your knees to the codger, (points to the Captain)

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Oh! what is this world come to! I bid a ſon aſk his father's bleſſing, and he ſays holloa! death and ouns, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Son! this—

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: I tell you, that's the boy in the baſket, the child of charity, the prentice to—Mr. Darumple, the fiddle-caſe maker; the private ſoldier, that for glory prefers a French bullet to an Engliſh plumb-pudding.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Sir, my birth has been a myſtery—and is it thus explained?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It muſt be the deſerted ſon—

sp.speaker: Nip.
sp.p: Of an abandon'd father.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nipperkin, you're now privileged—The ſervice you've rendered me by this diſcovery—my boy a brave ſoldier!—muſt make a good officer.

sp.speaker: Lenox.
sp.p: Sir, my higheſt ambition is now to partake the glories of the enterprize as a private, for if I am to be honour'd with promotion I'll firſt with the heart, hand and ardour of a Britiſh Soldier endeavour to deſerve it.

lg.l: Till to your cliffs we turn our face,
Old England be a merry place;
To pipe and fiddle, jig a-pace,
Whilſt we take hence our drumming;
But if we finiſh the campaign,
With wooden leg, or golden chain,
We'll march, or hop to you, again,
You ſing, our boys are coming.

sp.speaker: CHORUS.
sp.l: Till to your cliffs &c.

lg.l: Ye warriours, from my ſoldier fly,
The lightnings flaſh his beaming eye;
Beneath his conquering ſword ye die,
If to the fight ye dare him.
When you my love to battle go,
Your foot upon the vanquiſh'd foe,
Your arm rais'd high, to give the blow,
For his lov'd ſweetheart, ſpare him.
Till to your cliffs. &c
I'm given much to knock and kill,
This war was made againſt my will;
Some like to fight, but I'll ſit ſtill,
And talk in coffee houſes:
But if I took it in my head,
By cutting throats to get my bread,
In moſt newſpapers might be read,
My mighty kicks and douces.
Till to your cliffs, &c.
But grateful hearts we hence muſt bear.
For all thoſe noble Britiſh Fair,
Who take into their gen'rous care,
Dear pledges left behind us.
You to protect, the powr'ful charm,
That fires the ſoul and nerves the arm,
Whilſt patriots zeal our boſoms warm,
Such duties ever bind us.
Till to your cliffs, &c.
We go brave lads at honour's call,
To check the proud, the ruthleſs Gaul,
Let Britain's thunder now appall,
And bid him think on Creſſy.
I'll weigh for Holland, with a cheer,
And when I've help'd my friend Mynheer,
I'll round for bonny Pylmonth ſteer,
And buſs Poll, Sall, and Beſſy.
Till to your cliffs, &c.
You Wolfs and Elliots all repair,
Great Britain's ſtandard, Io! I bear;
My colours ſlaping in the air,
His Majeſty was donor.
And, ladies, do not think I jeſt,
My courage when put to the teſt,
For your dear ſakes I'll fight my beſt,
I will, upon my honor.
Till to your cliffs we turn our face,
Old England be a merry place;
To pipe and fiddle, jig a-pace,
Whilſt we take hence our drumming.
